statement:
We state the existence of the essential supremum for a set $\mathcal{S}$
of extended real valued functions on a measure space
$(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mu)$.

Suppose that the measure space $(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mu)$ is
$\sigma$-finite. Then, the essential supremum of $\mathcal{S}$ exists.
Furthermore, if $\mathcal{S}$ is nonempty then there exists a sequence
$(f_n)_{n=1,2,\ldots}$ in $\mathcal{S}$ such that $$\label{eq:1}
\operatorname{esssup}\mathcal{S}=\sup_n f_n.$$

Note that, by reversing the inequalities, this result also applies to
the essential infimum, except that equation (\[eq:1\]) is replaced by
$$\operatorname{essinf}\mathcal{S}=\inf_nf_n.$$
